text: Yeah okay First of all I'd just like to ask you a personal question about how you got started back in science fiction years ago How I got started reading it or how I got started writing it Reading it way back when you were in your teenage years Oh that's kind of that's kind of interesting Most people don't believe this story but I actually discovered science fiction when I was wandering around a garbage dump um there was a garbage dump a few blocks from our house and i like at that time when i was i guess about 10 or 11 or something sometimes friends and i would just go down and look around and see what people were drawing out and one day among the things that we found people who had thrown out were a couple of old bolt magazines from the year before uh amazing stories and i think there was one amazing stories and one fantastic adventures those being companion magazines so i grabbed of those and brought them home. And I loved them. I got hooked right there. I started looking for the magazines on the newsstand. And of course found that there were a whole lot of other magazines on the newsstands. Planes' Stories, Starling Stories, Astounding, Thrilling Winter Stories, Weird Tales. And began buying all of them almost immediately. Okay, what about how you got involved in the fan movement, the fan structure? Well, that drew right directly out of the reading of the Polk Magazine, because at that time, every magazine being published had a letter column, usually a long letter column, full of letters from the readers saying what they had thought of the previous issue, and often asking for correspondence, and their addresses would be published there. So I began writing to anybody who was living around the San Francisco area where I was living then. And got into correspondence with, I guess, about two or three different people. And through them, I got in touch with the local science fiction club, the Golden Gate Futurian Society. And I joined that. And at the same time, of course, a number of the magazines were running fanzine review columns. And I simply sent off a bunch of fanzines and immediately began writing for them. At that time, the first things, of course, I was writing were amateur science fiction stories, which were quite terrible, but a whole lot of them got published in those early fanzines. And shortly thereafter, began branching out and doing other things, critical articles and things like that. I don't think I actually published a fanzine for several years. It was 1952 when I published my first one. Because I was too young. I didn't have any money and no experience and things like that. So I gradually worked my way into publishing fanzines. During the 50s and then on through the 60s I was very prolific at publishing fanzines. I still do publish them occasionally, but not too often these days. I simply don't have time. I know this is an obvious question, but I imagine a lot of our listeners may not know this. Could you just briefly explain what a fanzine is? Yeah. Fanzines are amateur magazines, usually not published for profit, you know, not even with hope of profit, published by readers of science fiction, usually dealing either directly or indirectly with science fiction itself. Articles on science fiction, articles on science fiction writers or science fiction fans themselves. And sometimes just on the things that interest science fiction fans, because of course the people who read science fiction have a wide variety of interests, but the particular interests of science fiction fans tend to be more intellectual, more scientifically oriented so that it's worthwhile for science fiction readers to publish things and just get in contact with other people who read the same things they do and think about the same things they do a typical science fiction fan, especially in the 50s before science fiction was nearly as popular as it is today, was somebody who didn't know anybody else, had never met anybody else who was interested in science fiction. Probably most people who knew him or her felt that they were crazy or had terribly bad taste or something like that. So it was always fun to get in touch with other people who read the same things you did. And the fan movement grew out of that. The fan movement actually started about 1930, but of course I came in pretty late on that. It was going for a long time before I ever got into it. Okay, you won a Hugo, I believe, in 1959 for Best Fan Publication or something of that sort. Could you explain that? Yeah, I was publishing with a friend of mine named Ronnie, like, a fanzine called Fan Act, which is a science fiction. Right. All right. Mr. Carr? Yes? Hold on, please. We have a technical problem on this end. Alright That's very strange, okay As soon as I told you we had a technical problem We no longer have the technical problem I'll be right back, hang on Okay It happened when you touched that Did it have any of you with it? No, it happened in between One of your questions We've got a problem with this line right here But it doesn't Give us any problem unless you move it while you're talking I don't know, just don't move anything, did he? Okay. Now, where are we? You were, I think, in the middle of your answer about the Hugo for Fanac. Why don't we just start that one again, because we missed about a 30-second hunk of it there. Okay. In 1958, I started publishing a science fiction fanzine, news magazine called Fanax, which is science fiction language for fan activity. I was publishing it with a friend of mine named Ronnie, who has since died. And we were reporting on the things that other fans were doing. The fanzines are publishing conventions that were coming up. Things like that, of people who was getting married and children born and things like that. Sometimes we would report also on the things science fiction writers were writing or publishers were doing, magazines that were starting up or dying at the time. But we didn't concentrate on that because there were other science fiction fanzines that were devoted specifically to news about science fiction itself. And they were well established at that time, so we didn't want to compete with them. We concentrated on fandom itself. and we were publishing it every week like clockwork and it became very popular it became a point where I don't know everybody who got it said this is an indispensable thing to have if you're going to be in fandom because you'll never know what's going on etc it was a time when there were a lot of controversies going on in fandom and we were reporting on those and a lot of people got involved in it and indeed it was a very important fanzine for its time it also became popular because we didn't just report on the news we also commented on it and we were rather how shall I say sarcastic, ironic we didn't treat it with total seriousness if we thought something was absolutely silly we would say so and we would make fun of things and people like that aspect of it so a little over a year after we actually started the fanzines we received the Hugo Award as the best fanzine of the year that was given to us in 1959 Okay good for just a little while I'd like to go into your editing career I believe from 1964 1964 to 1971, you edited for Ace. Could you tell me what you did for that? Yeah, in 1964, I went to work for Ace Books as an editorial assistant, which actually meant that I was a low man on the totem pole. I was simply somebody who copied his manuscripts, went over them to make sure the spelling was correct and things like that. there were no topographical errors. And then proofread the books before they actually got published to make sure, once again, that there were no topographical errors in the typesetting. I would write blurbs, cover copy, kind of, you know, the things that are written on the front and back covers of paperback books to try to get you to be interested enough in the book to buy it. and at the same time I was reading a number of submissions that were coming in and if I saw something good I would pass it on to the editor so it was Daniel Volheim now the editor of Doll Books and gradually as things went along I just got more and more involved in that and worked my way up in the company a lot of my suggestions for things that I thought we ought to be doing were taken seriously and Facebook's and then did start doing a number of things that I had suggested. So I began getting this and that promotion. And I think after about the first three years, I became a senior editor there. And began a series called the Ace Science Fiction Specials, which was very much a departure for Ace books in particular, but for the entire field for that matter, because it was specifically designed to publish adult science fiction novels, not simply juvenile adventure. but serious novels using the science fiction genre as its format and packaged uniformly so that people would be able to recognize a new book in the series when it came out and packaged in such a way that, you know, it didn't have monsters chasing half-naked women on the covers. It had very good artwork by a team of artists called Leo and Diane Dillon, who later won a Hugo Award and won two Calicotte Awards and God knows what else they were extremely good artists I also began anthologizing very early when I started there John Waltham and I were collaborating on an anthology an annual anthology called World's Best Science Fiction and I gradually branched out from that since I had begun to have my name on anthologies. I began to do others for Doubleday and Fawcett Books and so on. That was actually how I got my start doing anthologies was the work that I was doing at Ace Books. Okay, good. That answered a lot of the other questions I would have about Ace too. How many series, like say the Universe series or the best science fiction of the year, how many continuing series anthologies are you doing right now? Right now, I'm doing exactly three. I'm doing the Universe Series, of which number 12 will be published in June by Double Day. I'm doing the Best Science Fiction of the Year, of which number 11 will be published in July by Timescape and paperback. And I'm doing Fantasy Annual, of which number 5 will be published in November, I believe, by Timescape. Fantasy Annual is another Best of the Year, but that is devoted to fantasy. I occasionally do individual anthologies, too, but mostly I try to concentrate on those series books. Weren't you doing one too, the best science fiction novellas of the year? Yeah, I did two volumes of the best science fiction novellas of the year a few years ago, and they simply did not sell well enough. Evidently, people wanted to have a greater variety in the length of their story, that they were reading. They didn't want to have five novellas all in one book. They wanted to have maybe two or three novellas and some novelettes and short stories all stuck together. So after the first two books, when that experiment didn't prove to be successful, it was simply dropped. And I moved to Best Science Fiction of the Year from the publishers of Best Science Fiction Novellas and Best Science Fiction of the Year who were Valentine Delray books over to Timescape Books and lengthened the book from, I think it was 125,000 words I was doing at that time. I lengthened it to 150,000 words so that I could put in one or two more novellas. And now I'm doing a much more balanced book than I was ever doing before. Essentially what I'm doing now is both of those books put together. Okay. Okay. The Universe Series, now that's totally original science fiction, right? Yes, it is. That's right. Could you explain the difference, say, to an author? I'm kind of hazy on this, like an author who has a story to sell. What's the difference between selling to an original anthology like that or a magazine like Analog or Amazing or something? There are all sorts of differences. There are both artistic and monetary differences. The one thing, if you sell to a magazine, then the money that you get from the magazine is simply the payment for that use of the story. If you sell it to an original anthology, that's going into a book, and you get an advance payment. But after that, you get a share of the royalties. If the book sells well, then there will be additional earnings on the book, and the individual authors will continue to make money for years thereafter, and indeed they do on universe because it does sell pretty well. So your chances of making money on your story are at least as good, I would say, in the original anthologies as they are in the science fiction magazines. Aside from that, there's also the fact that a lot of writers simply like to have their work appear in book form because they know it's going to be around to be read longer than a magazine will be. it'll stay in better shape and it'll be in libraries and things like that and there's also a certain cachet a certain prestige to appearing in one of the original anthologies because over the years the original anthologies have proven to be a source of much if not most of the best science fiction being published so that automatically if you sell to Universe or to New Dimensions, one of the other original anthology series. You know that your work is going to be appearing along with much of the other best work to appear in the year, and you also know that people are going to be looking for those books and expecting to find the best work, so that if you have a really good story, for instance, and maybe you think you have a chance at winning an award, a nebula, or a Hugo, or something like that, your chances are somewhat enhanced. if you're in one of these original anthologies, because people who are looking for the really top stories, think of those first. And I think, possibly, they tend to think of what has appeared in those first also when it comes time to nominate the thing. Or it may just be that the best stories do appear in those books. But in any case, I once did a breakdown of where the stories of the past ten years that have won Nebula's and or Hugo's had appeared. And there's a disproportionate amount. I think it's something like 40% of them had appeared in original stories anthologies. Okay. What about an editor's... Say your function as the editor of the Universe series. I mean, do you actively seek stories? Do you editorially comment and ask for changes in the stories? Like, what would be the difference between you doing that and, say, an editor for a magazine. There's not a great deal of difference between what I do as an editor and what a magazine editor will do. We both will work with an author if a story seems good enough to sell to us but not quite right. We want a few changes. Then, of course, we'll discuss them with the author and see if the author agrees and wants to make those changes. There's no difference there. The prime difference between the way I work, well, two differences between the way I work and the way magazine editors work. Number one, a magazine editor has a deadline every month to get a magazine out. So the magazine editor really has to have a certain number of stories to publish every month, whether or not enough really top stories have come in, the editor still has to publish the magazine. I don't have that problem. I get a contract, and I have about six months to put together a book. It usually takes me about two or three months to get enough stories, but if I need the full six months, I can do that. So I don't have a tight deadline, and I can keep my standards higher. Secondarily, I work differently from most of the magazine editors in that I have more time because I'm only doing one book a year. to go around to specific authors and ask them for a story that they're working on. They may not have that story ready for another three, four, or six months, but I can talk to them in advance and say, well, I'll be buying next April or something like that, so please send it to me then. Most of the stories that I get on submissions are from people I know either personally or through the mails as writers. from whom I've not solicited stories, whereas the magazines try to do that, but they're very heavily overworked editors at the magazines because they have these constant deadlines. And they don't have time, as much time as I do anyway, to go after individual authors and ask for stories. So I think there's a higher percentage of stories that I buy from authors I've asked for stories by. Okay, on the Best Science Fiction of the Year series, could you just tell me a little bit about the criteria you use to pick stories? Do you go only for the best stories, or do you look for balance? Do you look for the names, or what kind of criteria do you have? I go about 90% for the best stories. The names don't bother me because it always turns out that most of the best stories are by name writers This is how they became name writers in the first place, by writing good stories As I read during the year all year long sort of day by day, week by week, month by month every time I read a story that I think is a particularly good story a candidate for the best science fiction of the year or the best fantasy annual Old the Best Fantasy of the Year, I make a card and I put it in the card file. And that card will tell me the title of the author, where it appeared, how long it is, and give a brief precie of the plot. And at the end of the year, I simply go through those cards and pick out what I consider to be the best 150,000 words out of that. And then I look at that to see what the editorial balance is like. Um, I, I do want to be sure that there aren't too many stories that are down-to-depressing because that's just not fun to read. They may be good stories individually, but you can string them all end-to-end and, and they can actually, uh, seem not as good as they are. So, I try to work on that kind of balance, and I try to mix up the balance between longer stories and shorter stories because people do like variety in that. and if it should ever happen for instance that I think the best 15 stories of the year however many it takes are all time travel stories for instance I'm not going to publish a whole book full of time travel stories that's just silly again people would get tired of reading so many time travel stories in one book so I try to mix up the themes too but the editorial balance is really something that I do after I've chosen the best stories themselves and rarely does it make a great deal of difference in the balance of the book itself. Usually, there is a lot of variety in all of these things already so that I don't have to tinker too much. Okay, could you just give me maybe a little philosophy or theory behind an anthology? What kind of need does it fill? It's kind of a vague question, as best I know an anthology builds a need for people who want to read good science fiction short stories novelettes novellas whatever people who want to read something other than a novel probably people who want to have something they can dip into from time to time rather than sitting down and reading the whole thing straight through as they would a novel there's a different psychology between reading novels and short stories, and most people do prefer to read novels. They always sell better than anthologies or single-author short story collections. But there are people who like the short stories. I do, for instance. They're the people who buy these. For a reprint anthology, I think, you know, like the best science fiction of the year or some other kind of anthology, you know, the theme anthologies that come out. a whole bunch of stories about robots or something like that. On a repun anthology, the attraction, I think, is that these stories have been doubly screened. They're stories that were good enough in the first place to sell to the magazine, and beyond that, they are the best stories from the magazine. So the people who pick up an anthology can reasonably expect that that is going to contain more good stories than the average issue of a science fiction magazine. this isn't always true there's some very bad anthologies there's some very good issues of magazines but by and large that is the case I think ok, I know you've done a lot of theme or specialized anthologies I have a whole list of them here in front of me I just wanted to say pick out a couple and ask a question on them this earlier one called Science Fiction for People Who Hate Science Fiction how did you go about picking those stories? that was My first anthology that I did under my own name, and nobody else's name, it was, I think, in fact, the second anthology I did right after I first wrote about science fiction. And the idea on it was, I wanted a book that could be given to people who don't normally read science fiction, who think that they wouldn't like it. And I wanted, first, that the story should be good stories, And second, that the story should be accessible to people who don't know the specialized language of science fiction. There are a whole lot of assumptions that are just automatic in science fiction, and nobody bothers to explain them anymore. So there are a lot of stories that are published these days that really require a certain amount of background in reading science fiction in order to understand them. Nobody stops to explain what a star warp drive is anymore because that gets a little bit tiresome after a while. We all know how a Star Warp drive works, more or less. Or at least we think we do. But to somebody who's never heard of that before, that can be kind of confusing. Or the intricacies of the morality of robot behavior, or the strangeness of time paradoxes. Things like that can be very confusing. to someone first coming to science fiction. So the stories that I chose for that book were stories that had very simple dramatic ideas that were very easy to understand to someone who was not used to science fiction right away, but that were also very good stories. And the theory on the book was that people would buy that. A number of them would simply buy it for themselves, and also a number of them would buy it to give to friends theirs in hopes of convincing them that they might like science fiction, too. And the book sold pretty well. In fact, it's still in print and in a small favorite back edition. I think it was published about 16 years ago, and it's still in print. Good, yeah, I was going to ask if it was still in print. Yeah, it's in print from, I think it's a Collier book. Okay, another one I had a brief question on was a more recent one, Dream's Edge, science fiction stories about the future of the Planet Earth. I understand that was done sort of with the Sierra Club. Could you explain the origin or the impetus for that one? Yeah, the origin of that was that the Sierra Club themselves decided they wanted to publish a science fiction anthology. And they looked around for someone to do it, and they eventually landed on me, partly because I was known as an anthologist, and partly because the Sierra Club's main offices are in San Francisco, and I live nearby. So they got in touch with me, and we discussed the book. and I went ahead and put it together. The main problem I had with that book was that there were too many stories in it that were downbeat and depressing. If you start writing about the ecology of Earth, which is what the theme of that was, well, everything's going wrong these days, as you know, and nobody really has any answers about what we can do about it. And if people picked up that book to find that science fiction writers had the answers that were going to save us, they were going to be disappointed because there simply aren't any. If there were any answers, it wouldn't be in a science fiction book, you know. It would be something that was being done already. So even though I think all the stories in there are very good, there are only a few of them that hold out a whole lot of hope. Most of them are about the problem, the ironies of messing around with the environment and so on. I have to confess I haven't been able to find that book. Is it in paperback? Yeah, it's in a trade paperback, again, from Sierra Club Books. Okay, I'm a member of the Sierra Club, too, I just haven't been able to get a hold of that. I expect you can get it. It's probably on their back list somewhere. It was only published, what, about a year and a half ago. Okay, would it be fair to ask you? These are very small hard cutters anyway, so I'm sure that's out of print. But the paperback, that's much larger printing okay could I ask you if you have any particular favorites among the anthologies you put together yeah I have as a matter of fact a number of them are favorites of mine I think oh there are a number of the best science fiction of the year volumes that I think are extremely good just because they're a very good year a lot of good stories appeared in those years I couldn't tell you the exact numbers or the exact years, but there were some from the early 70s, for instance. One or two of the more recent ones, some of the ones from the late 60s, I think, are extremely good. There's one that had two novelettes by Roger Zelazny that he was just starting out in science fiction, was writing at the height of his powers, and a bunch of other good stories. But aside from that, there's an anthology that I did for Harper & Row about five years ago called Classic Science Fiction, The First Golden Age, which is a big, thick anthology of stories from 1940 to 1942, which is generally considered the time that science fiction first became really good. And I went back and read every one of the magazines, published in those three years, and there were very many of those magazines, and I chose all of the stories that I considered the best, most of which turned out to be pretty well-known stories. They're classic stories by his bootstraps, by Robert A. Heinlein, and the Twonky by Henry Kutner, and so on. But at the same time, I also did a lot of research on the writers, on the editors, the publishing companies, the artists, and so forth, the conditions under which they worked, how much money they were actually able to make. And I wrote a great deal of introductory material, background material about the writers and what they were doing and how they came to write each individual story. I interviewed these writers either in person or by mail. I looked through all the old magazines or whatever was said there. And since I collect old fanzines, I had a lot of the fan magazines that were published in the early 40s so that I had more or less direct information there too about what was happening. And I think the anthology itself contains a number of just classic stories It's a basic anthology for anybody's science fiction library. But in addition to that, that background material is fascinating. It tells a whole lot of things about how things happened and why they happened. And it also tells a number of pretty amusing stories about things that went on behind the scenes. I really enjoyed doing the book. Yeah, I'm familiar with that one. I've read that that's considered to be one of your best. Let me ask you one more question about your work as an editor. How does a freelance editor work anyhow? Do you make contracts with the authors and give them payment and then go to the publisher? Or what are the mechanics of that? The mechanics are that first I sell the book to the publisher. There's no way I can make a contact with the author unless I have some money to offer. So I go to the publisher first. The publisher buys it and gives me a contract which guarantees me a certain amount of money, whatever it is on any given book. and I then do my my buying from the authors and make individual contracts with them ok that explains it if you have a little more time I'd like to go on to just a little bit about your own writing sure ok from what I understand you had your first professional story published in 1962 what he who sucks with the devil or he who sucks with the devil I believe it was That's right, yes. Okay, could you tell me the, oh, I don't know, about when you decided you wanted to become a professional writer and, you know, how you got the first story published, just a little bit about that. Yeah, I, in 1961, I had been living in the Bay Area. And I suddenly decided I was going to just leave the Bay Area. I didn't like the way life was going here. I wasn't doing anything. I was 24 years old and didn't really have a direction to my life yet. So I went to New York City to visit with a friend of mine for a month or however long. And as soon as I got there, I thought, well, gee, I don't have a job. I really ought to do something to make some money. And I had been writing science fiction stories, as I said earlier, since I was a kid. I was 11 years old or so. So I turned back to writing science fiction. And at one point, I had a copy of that story, Who Sucks With the Devil? And I was actually working on another story. That story was on commission with a magazine, which wanted to buy it, but they weren't sure they were going to have a second issue or not. So it was kind of on hold. And the editor of fantasy and science fiction, Arvin Davidson, came into the office where I was working. It was an office where a number of us were working. And he had just become the editor. In fact, that day, he came in to announce to us that he was the new editor of fantasy and science fiction. And he saw that I was... And I said, well, the one I'm working on now isn't finished, but I do have this other one. And I showed him the carbon copy of that. He just, he went into the other room and read it and came back in five minutes and said he liked it and he would buy it, which totally blew my mind. You know, a guy just walks in the door and buys your first story like that. So he took that and in fact he bought the next half dozen stories that I wrote. In fact, thereafter, I haven't written a single story since that time that I haven't eventually been able to sell. I don't have any stories sitting in my trunk that are unsalvageable or anything like that. Okay. one thing that's puzzled me a little bit in 1973 you got another Hugo which I believe was for the best fan writer of the year that's right yeah how can you be considered a fan when you've been publishing professional science fiction there's nothing stopping you from being a fan just because you make your money writing professionally I didn't get that award for the stories that I was publishing in professional magazines. I got that for the material that I was writing for amateur magazines because I hadn't stopped doing that. I'm still interested in the amateur field. It's quite different from the professional field. And I had written a number of things the previous year, enough things that people liked that I managed to win that award that year. A lot of other people who have won that award are professionals and were professionals at the time that they won it. the first Hugo Ward the best fan writer went to Alexei Panshan who was a professional at the time the second went to Ted White who was a professional at the time and among the other people who have won her have been Bob Shaw who's won her twice he's been writing professionally for about 15 years and a number of other professional writers have won her people who have never sold professionally have also won her it's really just a matter of doing work in the amateur magazines, work that you give away for nothing, essentially, that you do for love, as opposed to work that you write for money. Okay, that's good enough. Your last novel, I guess it was published in 1977, Cirque, I've admired that book for some time. I know what the word Cirque means, I think, but I'm not sure why you picked it for the title. Could you explain that? I picked it for the title because I couldn't think of a better title, actually. And the more I thought about it, the more I realized that that was the inevitable title of the book. The book, of course, is about a city which is built around a gigantic chasm into the ground. And so the city is named Cirque, which is French for circle and has other connotations too. It also, for instance, it's the French word for circus and it was kind of a circus. There were a whole lot of things, strange things going on at once in the book. And the construction of the book is circular. It starts at dawn on one day and it goes ahead to finish at dawn the next day and it finishes at the same place in the city where it began with the same characters there. So in all those ways, Cirque or Circle was the perfect title for the book. The only thing it really had going against it is that nobody knows how to pronounce it or at least nobody is sure how to pronounce it. Yeah, I teach English here at Odessa College and I'm very sensitive to the way books are put together and I was very impressed with the tight structure of that, the coherence and the way you interwoe the various characters and brought them together at the end was just fascinating to me. It was very difficult to do because I didn't have an outline for the book. I was making it up as I went along. And the closer I got to the end, the more panicked I got about whether or not I was actually going to be able to pull it off. I actually had to do two drafts of it to make sure that it worked out properly. And I think it did. In fact, it worked out so neatly in the second to final draft that I actually had to go back through the ending and make a few things not quite as neat as they had been because it seemed a little bit too tight You said you weren't following a plan and so forth but I got the impression you were deliberately injecting symbolism or almost kind of an allegory into it with say the abyss that collects all the filth from the garbage and breeds these monsters which later turn into flowers and so forth, were you deliberately attempting a symbolic structure? Oh yes, that is definitely deliberate. I knew the general outline of the story I just didn't know the specifics of who was going to do what at which time and where they were going to be and so on. The symbolism is built into the whole concept of the story and I tried not to make that show too much on the top. I wanted the surface to be a story that was interesting in and of itself because I don't believe that symbolism itself should ever try to carry a story. That pours me to tears. On the other hand, if you have a good story up front and beneath that story is symbolism, preferably emotional symbolism, not just intellectual cuteness, I think that strengthens the story a good deal. There's a fair amount of symbolism in a number of my short stories too. Okay, at the end of that story it seems like everyone is better off Nikki, the girl with the multiple personalities, Annelly, the telepath Jamie, gloriana, they all discovered something it seems Could you explain what it is that they found out? Essentially what it is that they found out is that reality is what you make of it through various means some of them, I mean On the surface, again, it was a matter of coming to realize that you could make these monsters into flowers. This sounds silly when we talk about it. See why I don't like to talk about my plot. You could turn monsters into flowers simply by thinking of them as flowers, as something beautiful and good and pleasing because of the nature of the monster. But in other ways, all of the characters come to realize that they have control of their own lives, so they can look at their lives any way they want and they can do anything that they want. And so they all, in one way or another, by the end of the book, have made positive choices in their own lives as a result of the adventures they've gone through during the touring. I know it must be difficult for an author to get questions like that on his own work, but let me try one more on that book, The Millipede. he was part well I guess he was my favorite character in the book he seemed to be all knowing and in control of the situation and so forth why was he necessary for these people I mean why couldn't these people have found out what they needed to know without his part in the story so that again is built into the idea of the story actually he was there because I just love writing about aliens because I love writing a lot of straining minds about that. And that particular alien, by the way, is not a he, it's an it. And I was very careful not to say he anywhere in there. It's an alien who doesn't have any particular sex. But anyway, that alien sees time, both the future and the past. All is happening at once. And the alien is not so much in control of the situation as simply knowing what's going to happen and accepting it because it's inevitable. The future is as inevitable as the past to this alien. And the alien doesn't actually control what goes on, but the alien is a catalyst. Just as, for instance, I think it's Annalee who is the telepathic monitor is the ultimate catalyst because it is she who broadcasts telepathically to the other people her vision of exactly what can happen to make things work out better at the end. So it isn't really the Militide who does it, but had the Militide not been there, things would have happened differently because the Militide had its effect on Annelie and so forth and all the other characters. On the other hand, the Militide could not be there because, as the book is set up, the Milpede was there. The Milpede knows it. The Milpede, for instance, at one point, takes a great risk of getting killed. But the Milpede knows what's going to happen to it and knows that that risk and the pain that goes with it is going to happen. And indeed, the Milpede doesn't have any... The Milpede is the only character in the book who has no self-balition in that the Millipede knows exactly what the future holds and his power was to change it. Whereas the other people who are unable to see what the future holds do have the power to change things. And that's one of the things that actually comes out of the book. I don't think anybody's actually noticed that thought about this book, but most of the people have happy endings because they take over control 0-5. The millitide has a happy ending simply because the millitide what happens to the millitide was always going to be a happy ending and the millitide knew it. I don't know if that's coherent but it's difficult to talk about this kind of thing. It's very difficult to work with that concept in the book and try to make it coherent in the book. I think it works in the book because you follow what happened with the story. no I can follow that I got that out of the book personally just a second David we have to change tape now yeah listen I have about 5 or 10 more minutes could you give us that much more sure okay David has to switch the tape just a second we've got to turn it around Thank you.

segments.text: Yeah okay
First of all
I'd just like to ask you
a personal question
about how you got started
back in science fiction
years ago
How I got started
reading it
or how I got started
writing it
Reading it
way back when you were
in your teenage years
Oh that's kind of
that's kind of interesting
Most people don't believe
this story
but I actually discovered
science fiction
when I was wandering
around a garbage dump
um there was a garbage dump a few blocks from our house and i like at that time when i was i guess
about 10 or 11 or something sometimes friends and i would just go down and look around and see what
people were drawing out and one day among the things that we found people who had thrown out
were a couple of old bolt magazines from the year before uh amazing stories and i think there was
one amazing stories and one fantastic adventures those being companion magazines so i grabbed
of those and brought them home. And I loved them. I got hooked right there.
I started looking for the magazines on the newsstand.
And of course found that there were a whole lot of other magazines on the newsstands.
Planes' Stories, Starling Stories, Astounding, Thrilling Winter Stories, Weird Tales.
And began buying all of them almost immediately.
Okay, what about how you got involved in the fan movement, the fan structure?
Well, that drew right directly out of the reading of the Polk Magazine, because at that
time, every magazine being published had a letter column, usually a long letter column,
full of letters from the readers saying what they had thought of the previous issue, and
often asking for correspondence, and their addresses would be published there.
So I began writing to anybody who was living around the San Francisco area where I was
living then.
And got into correspondence with, I guess, about two or three different people.
And through them, I got in touch with the local science fiction club, the Golden Gate
Futurian Society.
And I joined that.
And at the same time, of course, a number of the magazines were running fanzine review columns.
And I simply sent off a bunch of fanzines and immediately began writing for them.
At that time, the first things, of course, I was writing were amateur science fiction stories, which were quite terrible, but a whole lot of them got published in those early fanzines.
And shortly thereafter, began branching out and doing other things, critical articles and things like that.
I don't think I actually published a fanzine for several years.
It was 1952 when I published my first one.
Because I was too young.
I didn't have any money and no experience and things like that.
So I gradually worked my way into publishing fanzines.
During the 50s and then on through the 60s I was very prolific at publishing fanzines.
I still do publish them occasionally, but not too often these days.
I simply don't have time.
I know this is an obvious question, but I imagine a lot of our listeners may not know this.
Could you just briefly explain what a fanzine is?
Yeah.
Fanzines are amateur magazines, usually not published for profit,
you know, not even with hope of profit,
published by readers of science fiction,
usually dealing either directly or indirectly
with science fiction itself.
Articles on science fiction,
articles on science fiction writers
or science fiction fans themselves.
And sometimes just on the things
that interest science fiction fans,
because of course the people who read science fiction
have a wide variety of interests,
but
the particular interests of science fiction
fans tend to be
more intellectual, more scientifically oriented
so that
it's worthwhile for
science fiction readers
to publish things and just get in contact
with other people who read the same things
they do and think about the same things they do
a typical science fiction
fan, especially in the 50s
before science fiction was nearly as popular as it is today,
was somebody who didn't know anybody else,
had never met anybody else who was interested in science fiction.
Probably most people who knew him or her felt that they were crazy
or had terribly bad taste or something like that.
So it was always fun to get in touch with other people
who read the same things you did.
And the fan movement grew out of that.
The fan movement actually started about 1930,
but of course I came in pretty late on that.
It was going for a long time before I ever got into it.
Okay, you won a Hugo, I believe, in 1959
for Best Fan Publication or something of that sort.
Could you explain that?
Yeah, I was publishing with a friend of mine
named Ronnie, like, a fanzine called Fan Act,
which is a science fiction.
Right.
All right.
Mr. Carr?
Yes?
Hold on, please.
We have a technical problem on this end.
Alright
That's very strange, okay
As soon as I told you we had a technical problem
We no longer have the technical problem
I'll be right back, hang on
Okay
It happened when you touched that
Did it have any of you with it?
No, it happened in between
One of your questions
We've got a problem with this line right here
But it doesn't
Give us any problem unless you move it while you're talking
I don't know, just don't move anything, did he?
Okay.
Now, where are we?
You were, I think, in the middle of your answer
about the Hugo for Fanac.
Why don't we just start that one again,
because we missed about a 30-second hunk of it there.
Okay.
In 1958, I started publishing
a science fiction fanzine,
news magazine called Fanax,
which is science fiction language
for fan activity.
I was publishing it with a friend of mine
named Ronnie, who has since died.
And we were reporting on the things
that other fans were doing.
The fanzines are publishing conventions
that were coming up.
Things like that,
of people who was getting married and children born and things like that.
Sometimes we would report also on the things science fiction writers were writing
or publishers were doing, magazines that were starting up or dying at the time.
But we didn't concentrate on that because there were other science fiction fanzines
that were devoted specifically to news about science fiction itself.
And they were well established at that time, so we didn't want to compete with them.
We concentrated on fandom itself.
and we were publishing it
every week
like clockwork
and it became very popular
it became a point where
I don't know
everybody who got it said
this is an indispensable thing to have
if you're going to be in fandom
because you'll never know
what's going on
etc
it was a time when
there were a lot of
controversies going on
in fandom
and we were reporting on those
and a lot of people got involved in it
and indeed it was a very important fanzine for its time
it also became popular because
we didn't just report on the news
we also commented on it
and we were rather
how shall I say
sarcastic, ironic
we didn't treat it with total seriousness
if we thought something was absolutely silly
we would say so
and we would make fun
of things
and people like
that aspect of it
so
a little over a year
after we actually
started the fanzines
we received
the Hugo Award
as the best
fanzine of the year
that was given
to us in 1959
Okay good
for just a little while
I'd like to go
into your editing career
I believe
from 1964
1964 to 1971, you edited for Ace.
Could you tell me what you did for that?
Yeah, in 1964, I went to work for Ace Books as an editorial assistant,
which actually meant that I was a low man on the totem pole.
I was simply somebody who copied his manuscripts,
went over them to make sure the spelling was correct and things like that.
there were no topographical errors.
And then proofread the books before they actually got published
to make sure, once again, that there were no topographical errors
in the typesetting.
I would write blurbs, cover copy, kind of, you know,
the things that are written on the front and back covers
of paperback books to try to get you to be interested enough
in the book to buy it.
and at the same time
I was reading
a number of
submissions
that were coming in
and if I saw
something good
I would pass it on
to the editor
so it was
Daniel Volheim
now the editor
of Doll Books
and gradually
as things went along
I just got more
and more involved
in that
and worked my way
up in the company
a lot of my suggestions
for things that
I thought we ought
to be doing
were taken seriously
and
Facebook's
and then did start doing a number of things that I had suggested.
So I began getting this and that promotion.
And I think after about the first three years, I became a senior editor there.
And began a series called the Ace Science Fiction Specials,
which was very much a departure for Ace books in particular,
but for the entire field for that matter,
because it was specifically designed to publish adult science fiction novels,
not simply juvenile adventure.
but serious novels using the science fiction genre as its format
and packaged uniformly so that people would be able to recognize
a new book in the series when it came out
and packaged in such a way that, you know,
it didn't have monsters chasing half-naked women on the covers.
It had very good artwork by a team of artists called Leo and Diane Dillon,
who later won
a Hugo Award
and won
two Calicotte Awards
and God knows
what else
they were
extremely good artists
I also began
anthologizing
very early
when I started
there
John Waltham
and I were
collaborating
on an anthology
an annual
anthology
called
World's Best
Science Fiction
and
I gradually
branched out
from that
since I
had begun
to have my
name on anthologies. I began to do others for Doubleday and
Fawcett Books and so on.
That was actually how I got my start doing anthologies
was the work that I was doing at Ace Books.
Okay, good. That answered a lot of the other questions I would have about Ace
too. How many series, like say
the Universe series or the best science fiction of the year, how many continuing series anthologies
are you doing right now?
Right now, I'm doing exactly three.
I'm doing the Universe Series,
of which number 12
will be published in June by Double Day.
I'm doing the Best Science Fiction
of the Year, of which
number 11 will be published in
July by Timescape and paperback.
And I'm doing
Fantasy Annual, of which
number 5 will be published in November,
I believe, by Timescape.
Fantasy Annual is another Best of the Year,
but that is devoted to fantasy.
I occasionally do
individual anthologies, too,
but mostly I try to concentrate
on those series books.
Weren't you doing one too,
the best science fiction novellas of the year?
Yeah, I did two volumes
of the best science fiction novellas of the year
a few years ago,
and they simply did not sell well enough.
Evidently, people
wanted to have
a greater variety in the length of their story,
that they were reading.
They didn't want to have five novellas all in one book.
They wanted to have maybe two or three novellas
and some novelettes and short stories all stuck together.
So after the first two books,
when that experiment didn't prove to be successful,
it was simply dropped.
And I moved to Best Science Fiction of the Year
from the publishers of Best Science Fiction Novellas
and Best Science Fiction of the Year
who were Valentine Delray books
over to Timescape Books
and lengthened the book from,
I think it was 125,000 words I was doing at that time.
I lengthened it to 150,000 words
so that I could put in one or two more novellas.
And now I'm doing a much more balanced book
than I was ever doing before.
Essentially what I'm doing now
is both of those books put together.
Okay.
Okay. The Universe Series, now that's totally original science fiction, right?
Yes, it is. That's right.
Could you explain the difference, say, to an author?
I'm kind of hazy on this, like an author who has a story to sell.
What's the difference between selling to an original anthology like that
or a magazine like Analog or Amazing or something?
There are all sorts of differences.
There are both artistic and monetary differences.
The one thing, if you sell to a magazine, then the money that you get from the magazine is simply the payment for that use of the story.
If you sell it to an original anthology, that's going into a book, and you get an advance payment.
But after that, you get a share of the royalties.
If the book sells well, then there will be additional earnings on the book,
and the individual authors will continue to make money for years thereafter,
and indeed they do on universe because it does sell pretty well.
So your chances of making money on your story are at least as good,
I would say, in the original anthologies as they are in the science fiction magazines.
Aside from that, there's also the fact that a lot of writers simply like to have their work appear in book form
because they know it's going to be around to be read longer than a magazine will be.
it'll stay in better shape
and it'll be in libraries
and things like that
and there's also
a certain cachet
a certain
prestige
to appearing in one of the original anthologies
because over the years
the original anthologies have proven
to be a source of
much if not
most of the best science fiction being
published
so that automatically if you sell
to Universe or to New Dimensions, one of the other original anthology series.
You know that your work is going to be appearing along with much of the other best work to
appear in the year, and you also know that people are going to be looking for those books
and expecting to find the best work, so that if you have a really good story, for instance,
and maybe you think you have a chance at winning an award, a nebula, or a Hugo, or something
like that, your chances are somewhat enhanced.
if you're in one of these original anthologies,
because people who are looking for the really top stories,
think of those first.
And I think, possibly,
they tend to think of what has appeared in those first also
when it comes time to nominate the thing.
Or it may just be that the best stories do appear in those books.
But in any case, I once did a breakdown
of where the stories of the past ten years
that have won Nebula's and or Hugo's
had appeared.
And there's a disproportionate amount.
I think it's something like 40% of them
had appeared in original stories anthologies.
Okay.
What about an editor's...
Say your function as the editor of the Universe series.
I mean, do you actively seek stories?
Do you editorially comment
and ask for changes in the stories?
Like, what would be the difference
between you doing that and, say, an editor for a magazine.
There's not a great deal of difference
between what I do as an editor
and what a magazine editor will do.
We both will work with an author
if a story seems good enough to sell to us
but not quite right.
We want a few changes.
Then, of course, we'll discuss them with the author
and see if the author agrees and wants to make those changes.
There's no difference there.
The prime difference between the way I work, well, two differences between the way I work
and the way magazine editors work.
Number one, a magazine editor has a deadline every month to get a magazine out.
So the magazine editor really has to have a certain number of stories to publish every month,
whether or not enough really top stories have come in,
the editor still has to publish the magazine.
I don't have that problem.
I get a contract, and I have about six months to put together a book.
It usually takes me about two or three months to get enough stories,
but if I need the full six months, I can do that.
So I don't have a tight deadline, and I can keep my standards higher.
Secondarily, I work differently from most of the magazine editors
in that I have more time because I'm only doing one book a year.
to go around to specific authors
and ask them for a story that they're working on.
They may not have that story ready
for another three, four, or six months,
but I can talk to them in advance
and say, well, I'll be buying next April
or something like that,
so please send it to me then.
Most of the stories that I get on submissions
are from people I know
either personally or through the mails as writers.
from whom I've not solicited stories,
whereas the magazines try to do that,
but they're very heavily overworked editors
at the magazines
because they have these constant deadlines.
And they don't have time,
as much time as I do anyway,
to go after individual authors
and ask for stories.
So I think there's a higher percentage
of stories that I buy from authors
I've asked for stories by.
Okay, on the Best Science Fiction of the Year series,
could you just tell me a little bit about the criteria you use to pick stories?
Do you go only for the best stories, or do you look for balance?
Do you look for the names, or what kind of criteria do you have?
I go about 90% for the best stories.
The names don't bother me
because it always turns out
that most of the best stories are by name writers
This is how they became name writers
in the first place, by writing good stories
As I read during the year
all year long
sort of day by day, week by week, month by month
every time I read a story
that I think is a particularly good story
a candidate
for the best science fiction of the year
or the best fantasy annual
Old the Best Fantasy of the Year,
I make a card and I put it in the card file.
And that card will tell me the title of the author,
where it appeared, how long it is,
and give a brief precie of the plot.
And at the end of the year,
I simply go through those cards
and pick out what I consider to be
the best 150,000 words out of that.
And then I look at that to see
what the editorial balance is like.
Um, I, I do want to be sure that there aren't too many stories that are down-to-depressing
because that's just not fun to read.
They may be good stories individually, but you can string them all end-to-end and, and
they can actually, uh, seem not as good as they are.
So, I try to work on that kind of balance, and I try to mix up the balance between longer
stories and shorter stories because people do like variety in that.
and if it should ever happen
for instance
that I think the best
15 stories of the year
however many it takes
are all
time travel stories
for instance
I'm not going to publish
a whole book
full of time travel stories
that's just silly
again people would get tired
of reading so many
time travel stories
in one book
so I try to mix up
the themes too
but the editorial balance
is really something
that I do
after I've chosen
the best stories
themselves
and rarely does it make a great deal of difference in the balance of the book itself.
Usually, there is a lot of variety in all of these things already
so that I don't have to tinker too much.
Okay, could you just give me maybe a little philosophy or theory behind an anthology?
What kind of need does it fill?
It's kind of a vague question,
as best I know
an anthology
builds a need
for people
who want to read
good science fiction
short stories
novelettes
novellas
whatever
people who want to read
something other
than a novel
probably people
who want to
have something
they can
dip into
from time to time
rather than
sitting down
and reading the
whole thing
straight through
as they would
a novel
there's a different
psychology
between reading
novels and
short stories,
and most people
do prefer to read novels.
They always sell better
than anthologies
or single-author
short story collections.
But there are people
who like the short stories.
I do, for instance.
They're the people
who buy these.
For a reprint anthology,
I think,
you know,
like the best
science fiction of the year
or some other
kind of anthology,
you know,
the theme anthologies
that come out.
a whole bunch of stories about robots or something like that.
On a repun anthology,
the attraction, I think, is that these stories have been doubly screened.
They're stories that were good enough in the first place
to sell to the magazine,
and beyond that, they are the best stories from the magazine.
So the people who pick up an anthology
can reasonably expect that that is going to contain
more good stories than the average issue of a science fiction magazine.
this isn't always true
there's some very bad anthologies
there's some very good issues of magazines
but by and large
that is the case I think
ok, I know you've done a lot of
theme or specialized anthologies
I have a whole list of them here in front of me
I just wanted to
say pick out a couple
and ask a question on them
this earlier one called
Science Fiction for People Who Hate Science Fiction
how did you go about
picking those stories?
that was
My first anthology that I did under my own name,
and nobody else's name,
it was, I think, in fact, the second anthology I did
right after I first wrote about science fiction.
And the idea on it was,
I wanted a book that could be given to people
who don't normally read science fiction,
who think that they wouldn't like it.
And I wanted, first, that the story should be good stories,
And second, that the story should be accessible to people
who don't know the specialized language of science fiction.
There are a whole lot of assumptions that are just automatic in science fiction,
and nobody bothers to explain them anymore.
So there are a lot of stories that are published these days
that really require a certain amount of background in reading science fiction
in order to understand them.
Nobody stops to explain what a star warp drive is anymore
because that gets a little bit tiresome after a while.
We all know how a Star Warp drive works, more or less.
Or at least we think we do.
But to somebody who's never heard of that before,
that can be kind of confusing.
Or the intricacies of the morality of robot behavior,
or the strangeness of time paradoxes.
Things like that can be very confusing.
to someone first coming to science fiction.
So the stories that I chose for that book
were stories that had very simple dramatic ideas
that were very easy to understand
to someone who was not used to science fiction right away,
but that were also very good stories.
And the theory on the book was that
people would buy that.
A number of them would simply buy it for themselves,
and also a number of them would buy it
to give to friends theirs
in hopes of convincing them that they might like science fiction, too.
And the book sold pretty well.
In fact, it's still in print and in a small favorite back edition.
I think it was published about 16 years ago, and it's still in print.
Good, yeah, I was going to ask if it was still in print.
Yeah, it's in print from, I think it's a Collier book.
Okay, another one I had a brief question on was a more recent one,
Dream's Edge, science fiction stories about the future of the Planet Earth.
I understand that was done sort of with the Sierra Club.
Could you explain the origin or the impetus for that one?
Yeah, the origin of that was that the Sierra Club themselves decided they wanted to publish a science fiction anthology.
And they looked around for someone to do it, and they eventually landed on me,
partly because I was known as an anthologist,
and partly because the Sierra Club's main offices are in San Francisco, and I live nearby.
So they got in touch with me, and we discussed the book.
and I went ahead and put it together.
The main problem I had with that book
was that there were too many stories in it
that were downbeat and depressing.
If you start writing about the ecology of Earth,
which is what the theme of that was,
well, everything's going wrong these days, as you know,
and nobody really has any answers
about what we can do about it.
And if people picked up that book
to find that science fiction writers
had the answers that were going to save us,
they were going to be disappointed
because there simply aren't any.
If there were any answers,
it wouldn't be in a science fiction book, you know.
It would be something that was being done already.
So even though I think all the stories in there are very good,
there are only a few of them
that hold out a whole lot of hope.
Most of them are about the problem,
the ironies of messing around
with the environment and so on.
I have to confess I haven't been able to find
that book. Is it in paperback?
Yeah, it's in a trade paperback,
again, from Sierra Club Books.
Okay, I'm a member of
the Sierra Club, too, I just haven't been able to get a hold
of that. I expect you can get it.
It's probably on their back list somewhere.
It was only published, what, about a year
and a half ago.
Okay, would it be fair to ask you?
These are very small hard cutters anyway,
so I'm sure that's out of print. But the paperback,
that's much larger printing
okay
could I ask you if you have any particular
favorites among the anthologies you put
together
yeah I have
as a matter of fact
a number of
them are favorites of mine I think
oh there are
a number of the best science fiction of the year volumes
that I think are extremely good
just because they're a very good year
a lot of good stories appeared in those years
I couldn't tell you the exact numbers or the exact years,
but there were some from the early 70s, for instance.
One or two of the more recent ones,
some of the ones from the late 60s, I think, are extremely good.
There's one that had two novelettes by Roger Zelazny
that he was just starting out in science fiction,
was writing at the height of his powers,
and a bunch of other good stories.
But aside from that,
there's an anthology that I did for Harper & Row
about five years ago
called Classic Science Fiction,
The First Golden Age,
which is a big, thick anthology
of stories from 1940
which is generally considered the time that
science fiction first became really good.
And I
went back and read
every one of the magazines, published in those
three years, and there were very many of those
magazines, and I
chose all of the stories
that I considered the best,
most of which turned out to be
pretty well-known stories.
They're classic stories
by his bootstraps,
by Robert A. Heinlein,
and the Twonky by Henry Kutner,
and so on.
But at the same time,
I also did a lot of research
on the writers,
on the editors,
the publishing companies,
the artists, and so forth,
the conditions under which they worked,
how much money they were actually able to make.
And I wrote a great deal
of introductory material,
background material
about the writers
and what they were doing and how they came to write each individual story.
I interviewed these writers either in person or by mail.
I looked through all the old magazines or whatever was said there.
And since I collect old fanzines, I had a lot of the fan magazines
that were published in the early 40s
so that I had more or less direct information there too
about what was happening.
And I think the anthology itself contains a number of just classic stories
It's a basic anthology for anybody's science fiction library.
But in addition to that, that background material is fascinating.
It tells a whole lot of things about how things happened and why they happened.

The mechanics are that first I sell the book to the publisher.

So I go to the publisher first.
The publisher buys it and gives me a contract which guarantees me a certain amount of money,

I picked it for the title
because I couldn't think of a better title, actually.
And the more I thought about it,
the more I realized that that was the inevitable title of the book.
The book, of course, is about a city
which is built around a gigantic chasm into the ground.
And so the city is named Cirque,
which is French for circle
and has other connotations too.
It also, for instance,
it's the French word for circus
and it was kind of a circus.
There were a whole lot of things,
strange things going on at once in the book.
And the construction of the book
is circular.
It starts at dawn on one day
and it goes ahead to finish
at dawn the next day
and it finishes at the same
place in the city where
it began with the same
characters there.
So in all those ways, Cirque
or Circle was
the perfect title for the book.

the coherence and the way you interwoe
the various characters and brought them together
